title: EL Spelling
description: Master spelling and reading through visual memory techniques and optimal learning methods. Learn to spell any word using proven visual learning techniques.

lessons.title: Introduction
lessons.description: Welcome to the Empowering Learning for Spelling programme with Allen O'Donoghue

sections.content: Welcome to the Programme
Hello and welcome to the Empowering Learning for Spelling programme. My name is Allen O'Donoghue and I'm going to be your guide through this journey.

So let me ask you a question. What are we here for? Maybe some of us have struggled with spelling in the past or with maths or just learning in general. Sometimes maybe we have to go into classrooms and feel like we're the only one there who it just doesn't click for.

Well, guess what? I'm here to tell you you're not stupid. It's just that we all learn in very different ways. Some of us learn exactly how school teaches. Some of us maybe struggle that way. But today I'm going to show you a very simple technique that will help you to spell more effectively.
What to Expect

Now, we don't do guarantees here, but I kind of guarantee that probably on day one, you'll be able to spell words that you never thought you'd be able to spell. And you're going to amaze the people around you.
All you're going to need is one of these and one of these. And I suppose you probably need an adult to give you a hand just to get started on the practice.
So let's dive into the next module and get this started because you're going to start to blow everybody's mind and maybe even blow your own one. Let's jump in.

lessons.title: The Optimal Learning State
lessons.description: Learn to calm your mind and prepare for effective learning

sections.content: Getting Into the Right State
OK, before we even get started on the technique, we've got to get ourselves into a nice calm state which helps us learn. It's what we call the optimal learning state. Sounds very fancy but it's not.

In our experience, a lot of people who struggle with spelling and learning in school are very visual, so maybe you're very good at art or coming up with stories or being very creative. Well, what we're going to show you today uses that visual memory that you have, but what we've got to do is learn to control that visual memory in order to help us learn.
The Big Strong Tree Technique

So, what I'm going to say is, if you haven't, please go back to the learning state and find one of the techniques that works best for you, just to help to calm yourself down. Now, for me, the easiest one is the big strong tree. So, pause this video and do your big strong tree or whichever one of the learning state processes helps you and then come back and press play.

OK, now you're back. Hopefully you are feeling a bit calmer and a bit more relaxed. You're breathing nice and deeply and everything is just chilled. Right, now we're in the optimal learning state which gives us the best chance of keeping the information in and now we're ready to move on to the simple steps. Let's move on to the next module.

lessons.title: Empowering Learning - Nouns
lessons.description: Learn the step-by-step technique for spelling words you can picture

sections.content: The Visual Spelling Technique

Okay, so now we're in the optimal learning state, we're going to learn how to spell. Now, the first thing we're going to do is we're going to do it with nouns. Nouns are people, places, and things. So, cat, dog, house, man, woman, all of those are nouns. And the reason we start with nouns is because we can picture them. We can see them in our mind's eye.

So, what I'm going to get you to do is I'm going to get you to ask your child to picture their dog. Now, if they don't have a dog, they can picture a friend's dog or a dog they've seen on the street or a dog from a movie. It doesn't matter. The important thing is that they can see the dog in their mind.

Now, when they tell you that they can see the dog, ask them where is the dog? And they might point over here or over there or up there. Wherever they point, that's where their visual field is. And it's really important that we keep the visual field up. When we look down, that takes us into our emotional state. And if we have a negative emotion attached to learning or spelling or our own ability, then that's going to take us into that space where we can't learn the story that we tell ourselves.
So by lifting it up, it keeps the logical part of our brain, the prefrontal cortex open, and that's what we need in order to be able to do this process.
Step by Step Process

So, the next step is, once we have found it, so we'll say it's over here, and we'll ask our child, is the dog still or is it moving? If it's moving, get them to pause the dog. That shows them that they can control their visual field. Now, you might have a young person who can't, so get them to picture an imaginary remote control and press pause, and double-check. Is there any waggy ears? Tail? Tail? That's not a tail. Tongue hanging out? The waggy tail? If anything is moving, get them to pause it. If they're really struggling, maybe you can help them get grounded again by using one of the techniques from the Optimal Learning State.

Okay, once they've got the still image, what you're going to do is, in capital letters, write the letters of the dog onto your post-it notes, and then you're going to hold it up to where your child's view is, and you're just going to ask them to take those letters and stick them onto the dog. Now, it's really important that we make sure that the letters they're sticking on are a different colour to the actual dog.

So, maybe ask them, what colour is the dog? They might say pink. Brilliant! It shows they're using their creative mind. Let's not correct them and get them to pick something different, or pick a different type of dog. It's their visual field. It's really important we do as little to try and influence what they're seeing as possible. So, ask them to place those letters onto the side of the dog, not above the dog, not below the dog, or not beside the dog, but on the dog.
Testing and Practice

When they tell you that they have the letters on the dog, you take down the post-it notes, making sure that they can see them. Ask them, what colour are the letters? They might go blue. Make sure, again, that the colours are not the same as the colour of the dog. And when they tell you the colour, ask them to spell dog.

They will probably go d-o-g. Then we ask them to change the colour of the letters to red, and ask them to spell dog in reverse. Not backwards, in reverse. And watch them go g-o-d. You might even see their head moving, as if they're reading from an imaginary script, because they are. That's how they learn.

The reason we ask them to spell in reverse is because if they spell it forwards correctly, it may be a word they know already. Now, you guys might be sitting at home right now going, Alan, we know how to spell the word dog. That's okay. Right now, it's not about necessarily the words, it's about practising the technique.

So, off you go, pause this, and start to play around with words. Start with three-letter words, and if your child's moving through those pretty quickly, go to four-letter words. Then you can build up to five, but let's not run before we can walk. The other thing I'd say is, it's okay if we make mistakes. So, if your child spells correctly forwards, but makes a mistake in reverse, go, that's okay, let's just do the process again.

You ask them to visualise the dog. Is it still or is it moving? When it's still, hold up the post-its and ask them to place the word onto the dog. When they're ready, they'll tell you, don't say, you're ready, ask them, are you ready? They might go yes, they might go no, leave it for as long as they want, and when they say yes, you take it down, ask them the colour of the letters, get them to spell the word, then ask them to change the colour of the letters and spell it in reverse. Right, off you go and have some fun, play around with it.

lessons.title: Empowering Learning - Non-Nouns
lessons.description: Learn to spell words that don't have a picture using the whiteboard technique

sections.content: Celebrating Your Progress

Okay, how much fun was that? I bet you guys spelled words that you didn't expect to spell. Congratulations. Sometimes we see people stay around the three or four letter mark. Sometimes we see people move to the nine, ten, eleven letter mark. I guarantee some of you parents out there, your jaw was on the floor when you were listening to your child spelling the words in reverse. It is mind blowing. It's the reason this is my favourite programme of all the programmes I run to ever work on because you see people just go, well I can do that. That's easy.
So that's great for all the nouns that we've done. Now I'm going to show you how to do it for the non-nouns. Those words that don't have a picture.
Creating Your Mental Whiteboard

So the very first thing we're going to do is get our child to picture a swan. Ask them, is the swan still or is it moving? Once they've got it still, we're going to ask them to place the letters onto the swan. Once they've told you that the swan has the letters on it, we'll take it down, ask them what colour are the letters, get them to spell swan, which they will do because they have the technique already. Then we'll ask them to change the colour of the letters and spell swan in reverse.

Now, if they pick the colour white for the letters, get them to change it because it's very hard to see white on a white background. Once they've spelled it correctly in reverse, then what you do is you get them to let the swan swim away and leave the letters. When they tell you that it's done, they now have their whiteboard and any word can go onto the whiteboard. It's fantastic.
Using the Whiteboard for Any Word

So then what you do is ask them, are the letters still there for swan? Yes, they are. Okay, what colour are the letters? Get them to spell swan, change the colour of the letters and spell it in reverse. And once they have it right, now we're flying. We can do whatever words we want.

So, as a practice, what we can do is get them to spell the word smell because most of us can't see smells unless your dad is pretty stinky and you know, you can see his farts, right? But we're going to get them to place the letters onto their imaginary whiteboard. When it's there, take it down. Ask them what colour are the letters, never white, and ask them to spell the word smell. Once they've done it correctly, get them to change the colour of the letters and spell it in reverse.

Okay, it's that simple. Off you go and practice as many words as they want to practice. Sometimes they will go, I want to keep going at this. Other times they might go, I'm kind of getting tired. That's okay. If they're getting tired, there is no point in trying to force things through to get more and more. Some days, okay, we say practice for five minutes a day for 28 days. But some days you might only get five words. Some days you might only get two words. That's okay. It's about practicing the technique right now. It's not necessarily about getting the words to remember the words. Okay, off you go. Go have some fun and let us know how you get on.

lessons.title: Conclusion - Final Tips
lessons.description: Important tips for success and next steps in your spelling journey

sections.content: Congratulations!

Congratulations! You've done it! You've completed the Empowering Learning for Spelling programme. Didn't I tell you it was easy? I hope you folks are all walking on cloud nine now, knowing that you can spell. I'm going to give you a few little pointers though.

So parents, it's important to go and talk to your child's teacher. Let them know that this is the technique that they're using to spell because if your child's visual field is up here and the teacher comes this way and says, spell something for me and your child looks out the window. It's important that the teacher knows my child's not being rude, he's just picturing or she's just picturing whatever the word is that they're trying to spell for you.
It's Okay to Make Mistakes

Also, like I said at the very start, it is okay if we make mistakes. That includes you parents. So kids, don't go too hard on your parents if they're making mistakes. When we're learning a new skill, it can take a little bit of time. We will probably make mistakes. That's okay.

The other thing I'd say parents is don't put too much pressure on yourselves or your young people. This is going to work, I promise you. It has worked for hundreds and hundreds of young people that we've worked with over the years. There has never been any young person that I came across that it didn't work for even in a simple small way. This will work. It will teach your child how to spell more effectively and keep using this at home.
Reinforcement Tips

Another really, really simple little trick is that once your child spells a noun, get them to stick it around the house. So if your child spells chair, get them to stick the word on the chair. If they spell door, stick it on the door. If they spell dog, please don't stick it on the dog. But if they spell mum, stick it on you. And yeah, what that does is it provides reinforcement for the child because they keep seeing it.

Now, some of us like our homes to be nice and not have post-it notes and sticky notes all around the place. But what's more important? A nice pretty house or your child's confidence in their ability to learn and no more or certainly less arguments around homework time.
Final Words

Young people, thank you so much for doing this. I know that can sometimes be funny to hear, but we really appreciate you taking the time to practice this thing because we know that sometimes school and education can feel like we're really struggling. So you even taking the time to go through this process shows how fantastic you are. And guess what? We believe in you.

The more you practice this, the easier school can become. So stay tuned for more programs coming that can help. And I hope you've enjoyed it. Let us know what you think. Send us your feedback and best of luck. Go practice in.
